intro: Rumicastrum morrisae, commonly known as the Morris's rockcress, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many mustard plants, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils, adapting to harsh environmental conditions. Its leaves are usually narrow and covered in a fine layer of hair, which helps reduce water loss. Rumicastrum morrisae is a perennial species that produces yellow or white flowers, contributing to the biodiversity of its native habitat.
